content: does anyone else remember when youtube had 5 stars instead of likes/dislikes? those were simpler times
author: nostalgic_user_2008

content: FIRST POST!! omg i'm so excited to be here. been lurking for months but finally made an account. this community seems amazing ðŸ’•
author: newbie_dreams

content: my first email was xxdarkangel2003xx@yahoo.com and i thought i was SO cool. the x's made it edgy, you know?
author: reformed_emo_kid

content: ALL YOUR BASE ARE BELONG TO US - this meme literally broke the early internet and we all loved it
author: meme_archaeologist

content: logged into my livejournal for the first time in 10 years. my teenage angst posts are... wow. 'nobody understands my pain' with linkin park lyrics. peak 2006.
author: millennial_cringe

content: RIP Vine, you were perfect and they killed you. 6 seconds of pure creativity. now we have 60-second tiktoks that feel like movies
author: vine_mourner

content: remember when you had to actually LEARN html to make your myspace look good? <marquee> tags and glittery backgrounds everywhere
author: html_survivor

content: a/s/l? - three letters that defined a generation of internet kids. we were all 18/f/cali apparently
author: chatroom_veteran

content: Flash games were ART. newgrounds was our netflix. stick fight animations had better plots than most movies today
author: flash_defender

content: when limewire gave your computer 47 viruses but you finally got that one song you wanted. worth it? absolutely.
author: piracy_survivor

content: Logging off AIM with an away message was an ART FORM. 'brb homework :-(' but really going to play runescape for 6 hours
author: away_message_poet

content: spent 3 hours customizing my tumblr theme just to change it again tomorrow. the aesthetic must be PERFECT
author: tumblr_perfectionist

content: ORLY? YA RLY! NO WAI! - owl memes were peak internet humor and you can't convince me otherwise
author: owl_enthusiast

content: The cake is a lie. This phrase defined gaming culture for a decade. Portal was a masterpiece.
author: aperture_scientist

content: MSN Messenger nudges were either flirting or pure annoyance. No in between. *nudge* *nudge* *nudge*
author: nudge_victim

content: Forward this email to 10 friends or bad luck for 7 years! - and we actually did it because what if it was real???
author: chain_letter_believer

content: Firefox with 47 toolbars installed because every website wanted you to install their toolbar. How did we browse anything?
author: toolbar_collector

content: Dear diary, today I found out my crush liked my facebook status from 2 years ago. Does this mean something??? - livejournal entry
author: hopeless_romantic_2009

content: I can has cheezburger? - lolcats taught us that broken english + cute animals = internet gold
author: lolcat_historian

content: Digg was supposed to be the front page of the internet. Then v4 happened and we all fled to reddit. RIP digg.
author: digg_refugee

content: When Twitter was just 'what are you doing?' not 'what's happening?' Different energy. Simpler times.
author: twitter_historian

content: FIRST! - getting first comment was the highest honor on early internet. Now it's just spam bots.
author: first_comment_legend

content: Friendster -> Myspace -> Facebook -> Instagram -> TikTok. We've been through so many digital homes.
author: social_media_nomad

content: Dancing baby gif. Ally McBeal. The first viral internet sensation. Before we even knew what viral meant.
author: gif_pioneer

content: 'This video is not available in your country' - the phrase that taught us about VPNs
author: geo_blocked_soul

content: 'brb' meant 5 minutes. 'g2g' meant right now. 'ttyl' meant see you tomorrow. AIM had its own language.
author: aim_linguist

content: Remember when Wikipedia wasn't allowed as a source because 'anyone can edit it'? Now it's more reliable than most news.
author: wikipedia_defender

content: Collecting music on your iPod was an identity. Your taste defined you. Now it's all algorithmic recommendations.
author: ipod_curator

content: Rickrolling was peak internet trolling. Pure, harmless chaos. We'll never gonna give that up.
author: rickroll_veteran

content: 'Have you tried turning it off and on again?' - IT Crowd was documentary, not comedy
author: tech_support_survivor

content: Internet Explorer 6 was the devil but we all used it anyway. Those were dark times for web development.
author: css_nightmare_survivor

content: LEEROY JENKINS! This moment broke World of Warcraft and defined gaming forever. Pure chaos.
author: raid_historian

content: Netscape Navigator vs Internet Explorer. The first browser war. Simpler times when the web was wild.
author: browser_war_veteran

content: ICQ number was your digital identity. Mine was 8 digits. If you had 6 digits, you were internet royalty.
author: icq_elder

content: 'This page best viewed in Netscape 4.0 at 800x600' - web standards were just suggestions back then
author: resolution_rebel

content: You've got mail! That AOL notification was pure dopamine. Dial-up internet made every email precious.
author: dialup_nostalgic

content: Geocities websites with spinning gifs, under construction signs, and visitor counters. Peak web design.
author: geocities_architect

content: Badger badger badger mushroom mushroom! This song haunted our brains for years. No escape.
author: badger_victim

content: eBaum's World was where memes went to die. Stolen content empire but we loved it anyway.
author: ebaums_survivor

content: Yahoo Messenger chat rooms were the wild west. A/S/L was just the beginning of the chaos.
author: yahoo_chat_veteran

content: Xanga was where we posted song lyrics and thought we were poets. The cringe was real but beautiful.
author: xanga_poet

content: 'Error 404: Page Not Found' - this phrase defined early internet frustration. Links died daily.
author: broken_link_mourner

content: Hampster Dance was hypnotic nightmare fuel. Once you heard it, it never left your brain.
author: hampster_trauma_survivor

content: Slashdot effect could kill any website. Getting mentioned there was death by traffic. RIP servers.
author: slashdot_victim

content: When 'going viral' meant your computer had a virus, not your content was popular. Different times.
author: viral_confusion

content: Waiting 5 minutes for a single photo to load on dial-up. Made every image precious. Patience was everything.
author: dialup_monk

content: YTMND created the first meme culture. You're the man now dog! Random was an art form.
author: ytmnd_archaeologist

content: 'Mom hang up the phone I'm using the internet!' - dial-up struggles were real family drama.
author: dialup_family_survivor

content: Zombo.com: You can do anything at Zombo.com. The most mysterious website ever created.
author: zombo_philosopher

content: Something Awful forums spawned the internet's best and worst content. Goons ruled the early web.
author: something_awful_goon
